So here is the second dragon I made. I know it's not in the most logical order, Thorn is on the cover of the second book, but I think it's much more logical if Glaedr would be the dragon on Eldest. Because, you know, he is the Eldest. And the second dragon we meet. Anyway, I fully modeled it after the picture I added. I didn't use the picture that's on the cover of various other versions of Brisingr. I don't like that one, I think it's an ugly pic, and I'm used to this one, even though it has multiple optical illusions/mistakes if you look closely. Or if you try to make a 3D model of it. I did my best, and I think it worked out pretty well.
I must warn you though, that it doesn't look exactly like the screenshots I added. Those were with a billion faces... and the file size was 800MB. Nobody wants that. You won't see the details when printing anyway. So I made it smaller. Also, in the final version I learned how to combine the tentacle eyebrow thingies with the main body. So they are joined nicely, as opposed to the screenshots, where they are still separate (and ugly).
And yeah, you can already see the differences in versions. At first the beard was a whole bunch of interfering meshes, which didn't look so bad, but I was afraid it wouldn't print nicely, so I made a new one. I'll upload new screenshot when I feel like it. It really has been a lot of trouble to go from 1.000.000.000 faces to 150.000 faces (or something, I'm not very sure on the exact numbers).

I hope you guys like it, and next up will be Thorn.

If you like this one, you'll like Saphira Bjarstkular as well:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1470976

Sé onr sverder sitja hvass!

I looked closely at the picture I added, and made filled in the things that weren't included in the picture. I didn't use the other picture of Glaedr that features on the German cover for example, because it didn't match enough with this one, and because I don't like that one. I made everything in Mudbox

title: Low Profile Filament Guide for Prusa

description.text:
Low Profile, Wide mouth filament guide for an i2 Prusa.
Requires four small 4" cable ties to fasten it to the threaded rods. Update: Version 2 has been added, which has more rounded corners to prevent the filament from catching in the corners. It is recommended that it be mounted underneath the 8M rods.

• Print and clean.
  • Insert four 4" zip ties in the built in channels.
  • Install on the top rods of your mendel prusa.
    • Notes: The 4" zip ties need to be rather small to fit properly. The ones I used have a crossection of ~1mm X ~2.5 mm. This filament guide is loosely based on Manixx's, which I had previously been using, but found to not be adequately sturdy (due to my poor print quality, of course). Other filament guides I have looked at/printed extended too far above the threaded rods and interferred with my z-belt (my model only has one z motor). This filament guide is intended to be a sturdy guide to prevent the filament from a spool mounted above the printer from interfering with the z-belt or rubbing on the threaded rods.

comments.text: Thanks! Well matched. Good work. I can only suggests little bit bigger hole for cable ties ;)
comments.author: PlotMac

comments.text: Thanks! At some point, I will probably update it with more rounded corners to reduce the possibility of the filament catching on the corners. I am a novice modeler though, and I am still struggling with SketchUp to try and get the curved surfaces to meet up correctly.
comments.author: Rubidium

comments.text: Great design. Rubidium shows it zip-tied in the photo, but I didn't use them. The guide snaps tightly to the 8mm rods and stays in place. I mounted mine upside down
comments.author: RWallace

title: Puzzle Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a puzzle box that you can cut on a laser cutter and assemble with no additional parts. The panels on the cube faces move, and if you move them in the correct sequence, you will open the box! This is an adaption of Bruce Viney\'s \"Cubey 2\" for the laser cutter. His original plans (requiring traditional woodworking tools) are here: http://homepage.ntlworld.com/bruce.viney/plans.html

The svg files have been created in inkscape; you may wish to use the eps files instead. Print eighthinch.svg on eighth inch wood -- these parts make up the inner mechanism and the external panels. Print quarterinch.svg on quarter inch wood -- these parts make up the outside of the cube and the sliders that slot into each face and connect the outer panels to the inner mechanism. The images that show the puzzle unfolded and partially assembled are a useful reference for orientation of each of the sides and positioning of the inner pieces with respect to the outer cube faces. See http://homepage.ntlworld.com/bruce.viney/Cubey%202%20T-Plans.pdf for detailed instructions on how to assemble the parts. Some tips: The images showing the partial assembly may be helpful. Sand the faces down before assembling the box. This gets rid of the stickiness that\'s left over from the laser cutting and makes the wood look nicer. Test the box before gluing it together. Don\'t press the faces of the cube together too tightly when gluing the box together. Glue the sides together with the panels moved over the finger joints to ensure that the box will be openable.

comments.text: what would you suggest as a laser? not a co2 one.
comments.author: Will695

comments.text: Cool! Nice Design!
comments.author: TrotecCanada

comments.text: I made a variant of this for 3 and 6mm plywood by simply scaling by 1/(2.54/8/.3)=0.94488. Some parts are simply two identical 3mm pieces glued together, this could go on the 6mm wood instead. Found a mistake in the design though, one of the panels of the lid is wrong. I manually corrected that after cutting. Also, the tolerances are very tight, mine needed quite a bit of sanding. I recommend making it slightly bigger so the wood is less thick compared to the notches, then the sliding should work better.
comments.author: polyroy

comments.author: Jonas

comments.text: I've uploaded .dxf files that I exported from Inkscape with the default settings.  I don't have access to AutoCAD to test these, so let me know if they work out for you.
comments.author: Jonas

description.text:

Jumper to make a connection between the green "PSon" and black ground wire so you can turn on an ATX powersupply without using a mainboard.

Use at your own risk. I'm not responsible for any damage to your powersupply or anything else ;->

Printer Brand:

Leapfrog

Printer:

Creatr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Sliced with slic3r: High quality setting.
PLA 190 degrees

I've used 1.3mm circuit board pins (12mm long) for this jumper.

  • Solder a wire between two pins. To get the right distance between the pins i put the 2 pins in a old atx connector during soldering. Use an old one as the heat might damage the connector.
  • Print the connector and pause it just before the point where the 'cap' is printed.
  • Now comes the tricky part: carefully push the two pins into the connector without letting it come loose from the printbed.
  • Resume printing

Let me know.

author: AxMod3DPrint

description.text:
It's been a long 3 months, but I finally think that the OpenFuge is presentable to you all. My goal was to make an affordable, open-source centrifuge for home-use by DIY biohackers. As of now, it costs around $200 in parts only, with all parts being commercial, off-the-shelf. The Instructables page will be up soon for all of you who want to build your own. Enjoy! Specs (Observed):
G-Force: 6000 G's
RPM: 9000 RPM

description.text: Twas the night before the night before Christmas and all through my house, I scrambled and shambled to clean up theâ€¦houseâ€¦ It was Christmas eve-eve and my friends would soon be, here at my door with nothing to see! So while cleaning and prepping I had a new thought, why not combine Christmas and my friend MakerBot?! I took a quick break, a few minutes or so, and designed a tree that truly would glow! With some plastic some solder and a few LEDâ€™s, I created a tree for my friends to all see. When my friends all arrived they exclaimed â€wow thatâ€™s bright!â€, and thatâ€™s what I did on my Christmas eve-eve night. I designed a quick 2 color Christmas themed print that would hold a couple of LEDs and a 9v battery. The tree was printed in Nuclear Green and the base was printed in Fluorescent Red. The tree has holes to slide 5mm LEDs into and the back of the â€œMerry Christmasâ€ base has room to slide a 9v battery in sideways. The battery doubles as a stand when itâ€™s placed on a shelf and alternatively there is a notch near the top so it can be hung from a nail on your door. More info can be found in my blog post here: http://thenewhobbyist.com/2011/12/last-minute-christmas-door-decoration/

• Print the base (battery holder) and tree (LED holder)
  • Glue two parts together (I used some very strong hot glue from McMaster-Carr)
  • Solder LEDs together
  • Solder in a resistor (I used a 430Î© resistor I had lying around)
  • Solder in your 9v battery connector
  • Connect battery and be merry.

I wanted to print the Spidex Micro by Quaternium but my 3D printer isn't large enough. To work around this I traced the .STL files and created my own part files in Solidworks. In tracing these files and a reading the description I observed that the Spidex Micro was designed to be printed via CNC machine in lieu of additive manufacturing. 3D printing around complex geometry can be difficult to get right so I was delighted to observe that a design for CNC printing removed much of that complication.

Armed with CNC style concepts and a distaste for the positioning of the components on the Spidex Micro I set out to design my own version.

This build is centered around using the DJI Naza M V2 flight controller
Other flight controllers could be used with an adapter.
Let me know if you have a flight controller in mind for this build and I may create an adapter. I will definitely need the dimensions to do so and I recommend using a micrometer.

Part Print List

QTY (1) Shorty .................main frame
QTY (4) Arm Ext ...............extensions for arms
QTY (2) Leggz ..................the legs of the frame
QTY (4) Top Clip ...............fastens the shorty to the legs
QTY (4) Anchor .................anchors the arm extensions to shorty
QTY (1) FPV clip ...............holds the FPV camera
QTY (2) FPV Arm ..............attaches the FPV clip to the legs
QTY (1) Cam Clip ..............holds the mobius camera in the frame
QTY (1) Batt Clip ...............holds the battery in the frame
QTY (1) Upper tray ............holds various components
QTY (1) Lower tray ............holds various components

Total 22 parts

Assembly Instructions
  1. Take the upper and lower tray and sandwich the DJI Naza ensuring proper orientation (hint: the arrow on the naza should point in the same direction your camera is looking)
  2. Fit the NAZA sandwich into the holes in both sets of Leggz
  3. Fit the four nubs at the apex of the Leggz (two per set of Leggz) into the holes in the Shorty piece
  4. Press the four Top Clips through the nubs described in step 3 (note: this is supposed to be difficult as the tolerances are tight to avoid accidental loss of the clips during flight due to vibration and other mechanical agitation)
  5. Place the Arm Exts into their appropriate locations on Shorty
  6. Press in the Anchors through the Arn Exts and through shorty. If executed correctly the arm extensions will be snugly installed into Shorty
  7. Press the FPV Arms into the camera side of the front facing set of Leggz (middle hole)
  8. Press the FPV Clip onto the FPV Arms
  9. Install Mobius camera
  10. Install Mobius camera clip into hole under the nub described in step 3
  11. Install battery into aft area of frame
  12. Install battery clip into hole under the nub described in step 3

title: Nixie Tube VU Meter for Fiat 500 GPS Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The 2013 (and later?) Fiat 500's have a docking port in the dash for a TomTom GPS unit. I have had my eye on this docking port for some time, with the idea of making my own something to dock in there. Well, the day has finally arrived.

I purchased a 6E2 Nixie Tube VU Meter from eBay (http://r.ebay.com/CzhFCB), and designed a functional docking port and case for it.

Video of the board in operation is here: https://goo.gl/photos/i6NbzwVF3RGAupBG9

It is possible to print the entire dock and case in one print, it is recommended that you print them separately and glue them together with a few drops of superglue. The case is friction-fit - the board just slides in, and the back slides in under/behind the board. There is an optional shroud for the back of the Nixie tube, which might help with stray light.

The docking port is provided as a separate piece, because this may be useful for other projects. The docking port is designed to be printed as a single print on a dual extrusion printer, printing ABS for the shell, and flexible TPU for the interior part. This works well, and only requires minor cleanup. It is possible to print them separately, but this would require a lot of support material. As a dual extrusion model, most of the support for the ABS is provided by the TPU.

The original goal was to also draw power from the dock, and the part is designed to do this, but I have not yet fully decided whether to do this or not.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

All parts are in the same coordinate system as assembled, but it is recommended that you print the box, the dock, and the shroud as separate prints.

The dock is designed to be printed as a dual-extrusion model, with ABS for the shell and Flexible TPU for the insert. The TPU is to allow the flexibility needed to successfully 'dock' in the docking port. I originally tried this in ABS, but it was too fragile and tended to break off. TPU works well.

Assembly

Assuming you've printed the parts separately, add the flexible insert into the docking port shell, then glue the case on top of the docking port (note proper orientation) with a few drops of superglue. Then slide the Nixie board into the grooves in the case, then slide the back in. The shroud can optionally be added and held in place with a couple of drops of superglue as well.
The case was designed in Autodesk Fusion 360, and source files will be made available on request.

comments.text: what piece actually fits into the mount on the dash?

author: radu0295

print_settings.Notes:: The Y end stops take a lot of tension from the belt. Making them as strong as possible to prevent flexing is not a bad idea.

description.text:
If you have a question, first search in the Comments section. If you can't find an answer, then ask in a Comment. I will answer as fast and as much as I can.

And please, share your makes!

Updates

20171118 New video by 3D Make

20171112 New "Assembly" and "Extensions and Derivatives" sub-sections in the "How-to".

20160910 Alternative Z stage that uses metal LM6UU linear bearings. The bearings should snap in their receptacles. Tinkercad model is here.

20160614 New Z stage, now integrated into the Y end. Unimaginatively called "v2". Same gear, same pen holder, a bit stronger, a bit better (one less part, less screws).

Print these:

  • drawing_machine_y_end2_v2.obj, and
  • drawing_machine_z_stage_face_v2.obj

To replace these:

  • drawing_machine_y_end2.obj,
  • drawing_machine_z_stage.obj, and
  • drawing_machine_z_stage_face.obj.

20160505 updated some searches in the grocery list

Summary

My take on Misan's drawing machine. I made one with a grbl controller and a CNC shield and adapted Misan's parts to be 3D printed.

Please read Misan's instructions as well.

The Z stage does not use a servo, as in Misan's machine, but rather one of those cheap 28BYJ stepper motors you can find for 1.50$ on eBay.

NOTE: The photos are of the current prototype, some of the modifications to the various bits and pieces have not yet been tested.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it here.

Printer:

Wanhao i3 Duplicator

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15% minimum

Notes:

The Y end stops take a lot of tension from the belt. Making them as strong as possible to prevent flexing is not a bad idea.

Overview The drawing machine is a small three axis robot that controls a pen or any drawing implement over a canvas. It is a complete open source design and aims to teach the basics of robotics.
Budget for one is about 80$. You will need a 3D printer.
See below
40 hours

Model Files

The first model file shows all the pieces that are then isolated for your convenience into separate files.

For some reason, when you upload OBJ to Thingiverse, objects are rotated 90 degrees (clockwise) around the X axis. Rotate -90 degrees in your slicer before printing. Of course, the two model files that are in the STL format (they come directly from Misan's model) are not rotated. Go figure...

If you experience difficulties with the OBJ format, go to TinkerCad here, copy the project to your account and export to STL.

Grocery list

Definitely not 475$ worth of parts...

Below are some searches on eBay that you could use for your own machine. I am not affiliated with any of the vendors that those searches may yield. Please proceed with caution on eBay.

You will need:

1 x Arduino (any cheap clone will do) with USB cable

1 x CNC shield. Look for the ones with included jumpers. It's a drag when you don't have them and you need to configure microstepping.

3 x Stepper drivers

1 x 12V power supply (the one I have is a quite beefy 12.5A, salvaged from another project)

4 x 8 mm diameter rods, any length you want (by pairs though). I used 2 x 400mm for X and 2 x 300 mm for Y (recycled from printers and scanners.) With these lengths, and the new Z stage, I get about 312(X) x 212(Y) x 23(Z) mm of workspace.

2 x X lengths of 10 mm (or 3/8") threaded rod, with associated bolts, washers and nuts

8 x LM8UU linear bearings

2 x NEMA 17 steppers

Cables and connectors

5 x smooth idler pulleys (16 teeth or 10 mm, 3 mm bore)

2 x pulleys (16 teeth, 5 mm bore) (you can also use 20 teeth with different grbl settings)

GT2 belt: to know how much you need, add your X to your Y, multiply by two and add two inches for luck

An assortment of M3 bolts in various length and their nuts

For the Z stage:

1 x 28BYJ stepper motor (5V or 12V)

1 x M5 bolt to secure the pen to the Z carriage

2 x 60+ mm of 6 mm diameter rod (I got mine from an old scanner)

Assembly

Before installing the stepper drivers on the CNC shield, install jumpers for microstepping. I installed all three jumpers on the three axis. Such precision may not be necessary for the Z axis.

The 28BYJ can be 5V or 12V. It does not matter (see this article).
You may have to open the stepper to cut a trace on its PCB to disconnect the red wire (see here) and use: orange, pink, blue, yellow, in that order (blue, yellow, orange, pink should work too) Adjust the potentiometer on A4988 counter-clockwise until the motor runs but does not overheat (check this article for details).

The last model file and photograph show (hopefully) how it all fits together.

grbl

You will need to re-compile grbl to activate CoreXY control.

Before you compile, change config.h as such:

#define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<X_AXIS)
#define HOMING_CYCLE_1 (1<<Y_AXIS)

// and this below goes uncommented
#define COREXY

Control Software

For control, I am using bCNC. Neat package.
I use Inkscape with Gcodetools extension to generate gcode. YMMV.

grbl Settings (YMMV)

$4=0 (step enable invert, bool)
$5=0 (limit pins invert, bool)
$6=0 (probe pin invert, bool)
$10=3 (status report mask:00000011)
$11=0.010 (junction deviation, mm)
$12=0.002 (arc tolerance, mm)
$13=0 (report inches, bool)
$20=0 (soft limits, bool)
$21=1 (hard limits, bool)
$22=0 (homing cycle, bool)
$23=0 (homing dir invert mask:00000000)
$24=25.000 (homing feed, mm/min)
$25=500.000 (homing seek, mm/min)
$26=250 (homing debounce, msec)
$27=1.000 (homing pull-off, mm)
$100=96.000 (x, step/mm) or 80.000 if you used 20 teeth pulleys
$101=96.000 (y, step/mm) or 80.000 if you used 20 teeth pulleys
$102=814.000 (z, step/mm)
$110=20000.000 (x max rate, mm/min)
$111=20000.000 (y max rate, mm/min)
$112=2200.000 (z max rate, mm/min)
$120=200.000 (x accel, mm/sec^2)
$121=50.000 (y accel, mm/sec^2)
$122=200.000 (z accel, mm/sec^2)
$130=212.000 (x max travel, mm)
$131=312.000 (y max travel, mm)
$132=23.000 (z max travel, mm)

Extensions and Derivatives

For stronger Y axis ends, see Drawing Machine - thicker walls for rod fix screws by FiX2k.
For cable management see Simple tube system for the Drawing machine by Valiox.
To secure the drawing machine see Drawing machine brackets by RC-3D, and also Clamp for Drawing Machine by Floppynator.
For an alternative Z stage using LM8UU bearings see Drawing Machine, LM8UU derivative by gigl.

Thank you guys for your contributions!

This video was made by 3DMake. It shows the assembly step by step. Nice work!

Hello, and thank you for your tutorial, it is limpid.
I'm looking for an info that I can not find anywhere.
I would like to build a plotter robot that can write on a board a text that you type on an Android app (or other) via a Bluetooth connection. (HC06)
My question is about G-code. I would like to know if the g-code can be interpreted directly by arduino? Without going through a software "sender". The idea being to send a string by Bluetooth, that my program arduino reads it, character by character, and that, according to the letter that it finds, it triggers a function in which there will be the corresponding gcode .
Is the installation of the grbl library sufficient for the gcode typed in an arduino program to be interpreted and triggers the engines of my plotter?
Thank you for your help
comments.author: arnaudz

comments.text: Hi Arnaud,
comments.author: arnaudz

comments.text: Hello Cyul and thank you for your answer and your help
comments.author: cyul

comments.text:
Oh sorry I misunderstood.
I would tweak GRBL for that.
To keep things simple, hack into the terminal interface in GRBL and add code to detect some escape sequence (such as ... 0x1B) to set the stage for your own interpreter, then interpret your one-letter commands from within GRBL. Don't forget to include a way to go back to the normal interpreter and you're all set.
There should be enough space left on the micro for that.
comments.author: arnaudz

comments.text:
I don't think my coding level is high enough. Thank you very much for your help but I don't really understand what you mean in your last message. I'd love to understand but I don't know what you are talking about. I do not want to waste your time and I think I'm going to code every move for every letter and when the program will read a letter, it will call the function that will move the engines the right way. Without using G-code.
Another question, when I look at the passage of the belt, I imagine that your machine can not move on both axes at the same time is not it ?
comments.author: cyul

comments.text: It’s similar to a corexy system. You could read up on that. You can move axis simultaneously at different speeds.
comments.author: arnaudz

comments.text:
I had thought of having a second arduino that I already ordered, I have to study how to send the code. If you can give me a website where I could find the information it could be helpfull .Is it sufficient to send a g-code command line of the type "G00 X100 Y100", or should I learn like "a protocol" or a language to make the first arduino order a sequence to the second ?
Thank you very much.
comments.author: cyul

comments.text: Classic serial communications should do the trick. It is not overly complicated. Arduino pins 0 and 1 are RX and TX respectively. Just connect the TX of the first arduino to the RX of the second one, and again for RX(1) and TX(2), set the same speed as the default for GRBL (115200, n, 8, 1) and you're good to go. Now, you may have a problem communicating with the bluetooth module, as it also needs serial and there is only one serial port on the Atmega 328. So I would look for another bluetooth board that has its own embedded processor. Maybe something like this?
comments.author: arnaudz

comments.text:
Thank you for all your good advice.
I had thought of using a arduino mega if I still use G-code but, to explain the project, I noticed that a friend owning a restaurant waste a lot of time writing his menu of the day on all his many blackboards. He does not know anything about computers but I have time and I would like to make it easier for him.
The problem with the gcode is that I want the user interface to be as simple as possible and therefore it is necessary that the G-code is generated automatically by the application ... it seems more complicated. I'm inspired by your robot and that one: https://www.jjrobots.com/the-iboardbot/
I only need the "writing" part.
If you look at the iboardbot, when writing a text, it only does so in a single font, so either it gets a g-code prepared by the application (thanks to a Gcode database for each character) or he generates it himself according to what is sent to him. And I think it's more stable to send pure text to the arduino than a complete gcode. This avoids a too long connection between the application and the arduino. To complicate the task I want the text to adapt to the blackboard (with end-of-stroke sensor and stops moved according to the size of the table) so it seems to me easier to adapt the text by adding a variable of increasing "the size" of motor movements.
comments.author: cyul

comments.text:
Looks quite the project indeed :-)
I would definitely do everything in the Android app (including the scaling: you could use the phone gyros to measure the board) and send complete G-code by Bluetooth. I don't think there are quite enough resources on an Arduino to do all that you need. Maybe use a SBC such as a Raspberry Pi as a front end?

comments.text: So I'm coming across some issues. Not sure if the tolerances of my parts are off or what but the 28byj-48 motor doesn't seem to. Even working properly. I just want to finish this.
comments.author: cyul

comments.text:
Recheck the order of the wires on the 28byj, one inverted pair and it doesn't work.
Drastically reduce the feed rate on the Z axis (if you go too fast the stepper cannot follow) see setting $112. If it works, increase the value progressively until it doesn't, then reduce by 20% to be safe, that's how I found 2200 mm/s.
As a guideline, when everything is off, you should be able to move the z-stage up and down with enough force (you're running the reduction stage of the motor backwards, so be careful to apply progressive force). If it's stuck, concentrate on your mechanical parts.
Finally, you need a beefy power supply. I reused that of a small 3D printer (remember Makibox?). Not sure about the wall wart.

comments.text:
It looks like either the driver, or the wiring, or the stepper motor is faulty or not connected properly.
Given the power used by those small steppers, I would be surprised if the driver was overloaded. With the pot set in the middle, it should work. If not, try to connect a stepper motor from another axis and see what happens.
Another thing to try would be to remove the jumpers on the drivers and try without microstepping.

comments.author: MFanta

comments.text: What do you mean "it gives you finer control on the pen position."
comments.author: Tarasz

comments.text:
The servo technology is very crude: a simple motor rotates the axis and the position of the motor is fed back to the control circuit through a potentiometer. The circuit is constantly fighting to balance the PWM signal it receives with the analog value read from the potentiometer. The resolution (and repeatability) sucks. It's good to jerk the pen up and down and that's about it (plus, I hate the noise it makes).
The JYB28 stepper motor, on the other hand, is so demultiplicated that it takes about 2000 full steps to do one rotation (and it's almost silent). I don't remember from the top of my head how it translates in movement but let's say 3 cm per revolution. Provided you don't skip any step, and ignoring the play here and there, that's about 15 microns per step. Precise enough?
comments.author: Tarasz

comments.text: Thank you for your project. I have a question, why the stepper motor is better than a servo?
comments.author: Tarasz

comments.text:
Because that is what I had in my stash :-)
More seriously, it gives you finer control on the pen position.
comments.author: Tarasz

If you ever need to manually trigger a Verisure smartplug with a servo, this jacket got you covered.

I have used it in my garage opener project http://sixbynine.no/projects/smartplug

Use this chiller to keep your wine cool.  A small amount of water at the bottom of the chiller helps the ice wick away heat from the bottle.  
In Vino Veritas!
Print this with enough layers to make it waterproof.  When it comes to water carrying capability, not all filaments are the same, so testing your filament on a smaller container is a good idea.

An improvement to my original parametric pillow block by adding a retaining ring.
the STL file should be sized for a 608 skate bearing, m5 mounting bolts and m3 retaining ring bolts.
Lots of things are parameterized,you can remove the retaining ring, change the bearing size, thickness, lip size, mounting bolt size, tab thickness, pretty much everything.

This is an adapter to mount a pcb router to an I3 rework carriage. It is suggested to orient the print, using support material, so the carriage mount is vertical and the motor holder is horizontal and use 60% infill. This will yield the strongest print. I use Slic3R and it defaulted in the correct orientation. I sourced the motor from Aliexpress:

http://www.aliexpress.com/item/2015-NEW-Mini-Mirco-Electric-PCB-Motor-Drill-Press-Drilling-bits-Tool-Twist-Drill-12V/32580675006.html

The motor has an O.D. of 29mm.

There is also a small bracket that fastens to the side in order to keep the wires from ripping off the motor. Please rotate this 180 degrees from the picture, so that the recessed part of the screw holes are on top. It prints better this way. I used m3x12 plastic screws from Mcmaster:

(http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817A370)

I had them them at the house, but they were a little long. One of the screws touches the motor before tightening the clamp, so either change the source for your needs, or buy a shorter fastener for the holes. 10mm should probably be fine...

title: police light blinking box for RC- model, quadcopter, car, boat whatever

description.text:
This is a RC-model police light.

you can use it for any kind of RC vehicle like:
multirotors, cars, boats, robots or whatever.

Or use it for good cop and bad cop role games in your sleeping room.
YOUR WIFE WILL LOVE IT!

Its printed with transparent PET and black PLA.
It can be used with a 3S-Lipo or any 12V power source.


You need the following materials:

  • Red-Blue-DIY-Kit-Dual-Color-Detonation-Flashing-Light-
  • some "long" 2mm screws with bolts

remixed_from.title: Customizable direct drive extruder for E3D v6 hotend for Prusa i3 / Wilson / Geeetech

title: Customizable direct drive extruder for E3D v6 hotend for Prusa i3 (With Inductive Sensor Mount and 40MM Fans)

description.text:
IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR A BETTER EXTRUDER+E3D MOUNT, HERE'S MY NEW DESIGN, COMPLETELY SUPERIOR:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1552129

Remixed from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913

  • Added 12mm inductive sensor mount and cutaway for the cable to run under the stepper motor.
  • Added fan mount for 40mm print cooling fans (they are mirrored so just print 2 of the same). Rotate 90 degrees to print.
  • Changed mount to fit MK7 hobbed gear.
  • Changed mount to fit 608 bearing.

  • Added spacer piece to use M5 bolt instead of M8 to mount the bearing.

  • Added 8mm inductor probe variation.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

comments.text: How do you keep your bowden extruder from overheating?  If I don't turn up the voltage pot, it just clicks and grinds.  If I do, it overheats and won't move at all.
comments.author: Paradoxfox

comments.text: Could you possibly provide the source files? I would like to have a version for 8mm probes and would change that on my own if you are too busy.
comments.author: s_s_

comments.text: Done, added the 8mm probe mount, with space for a 13mm nut, let me know if the nut you have it bigger (flat to flat)
comments.author: s_s_

comments.text: Thank you, i just realized that i ordered a 12mm version. Thanks anyways!
comments.author: chinzw

comments.text: What carriage do I need to print to make this work?
comments.author: kevinrocksman

comments.text:
The standard i3 rework one would work. Here's an example:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:114745
comments.author: kevinrocksman

comments.text: Hello, nice design, I'm planning to come back to direct drive because it seems better than bowden for me in the end... could you please make a version with an 18mm hole fore a proximity sensor ?
comments.author: titi974

comments.text: Do you happen to have the measurements for the nut that comes with the 18mm sensor?
comments.author: titi974

comments.text: yes, the outer "diameter" if we can say that about the nut is of 24mm
comments.author: chinzw

comments.text: Yes of course, ill try and add it today. I would recomend sticking with bowden tough, if you check my bowden design, with a 50mm tube it works way better than direct drive. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1552129
comments.author: titi974

comments.text: and I have almost the same design in bowden for now :)
comments.author: chinzw

remixed_from.author: thedayowl
remixed_from.title: PrintRite DIY 3D Printer Fan Duct v3

title: DIY PrintRite fan duct for MK8 nozzle

description.text:
this is a remixes from Fan Duct v3 by thedayowl.

i made it for 2 reasons:
-first it offers me better results on overhangs on the 2 axis X and Y
-second reason is for temperature control : since i change my nozzle for this one -which is really cheap and print really well- but head is 10.5mm height, and i had somme issues to control hot end temp as the fan duct was cooling the nozzle. For this reason it might not fit with original nozzles.

it still use the mounting system from thedayowl, which is perfect as you can adjust the height of the duct.

Print doesn't need any support but there are several bridges

Edit 03/05/16:

V.003 U-shape upgrade to have a more convergent air flow. need support

V.004 Sewing-machine-socket shape it is V.003 upgrade to carry LEDs. It has a slot for 2 5050LED series connected and a cable path.
You will also need a resistance between 550 and 650 Ohms.
Need support.

New version => V005

Whats new :
-only 2 ducts
-in 2 parts, which makes it easier to mount/unmount for cleaning/changing nozzle
-more clearance = less risks of melt
-MUCH BETTER AIR FLOW

No support but need enough good bridge skills
Horyzontal walls are 0.8mm thick => set a layer height that will fit (0.1, 0.16 or 0.2)
Needs 2 M3*8mm screws and nuts
Still a slot for 2 5050 leds

Walter's PLA cooling tower test

Walter's Overhang Test Print

edit 07/2016 :
happy w/ last version, not in progress anymore!

comments.text: Where do you wire the fan to the mainboard?
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text:
I plug the filament cooler fan to the fan output, and the extruder cooler fan to a 12V output as always on (one of the 3 JST connector at the bottom laft of the mainboard)
I recommand to read the thedayowl's things to get all important infos about fan duct on printrite (full fan speed and shim part)
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: Thanks for your reply! I saw that fan speed fix, but I don't really want to solder a resister on. I was going to try to use it without the fix and see how it goes.
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
If you're confortable with soldering, it's a good upgrade ; it will make your fan wins 300% speed.
If you're not confortable w/ soldering, then don't do it.
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: I am okay with soldering, but not in small spaces because I am clumsy.
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
If there is a auto-cooling setup in your slicer, then the manual control through the Host software won't work. If you want to be able to manually control it, then you need to turn off the auto-cooling in your slicer.
Other solution is to edit the g-code before to start w/ the right command ; for marlin firmware it's M106 S(power value between 0 and 255)
That's for the filament cooler, which i guess you call the part cooler.
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: Interesting. Can you recommend a replacement? How do you know the stock power supply is inadequate?
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
I did have some prints that stop in the middle without visible reasons. Actually it happens when board miss some current. So you can go with any 12V power supply that delivers more than 5amps. I personnaly use this :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1698844
comments.author: bbstep

comments.text: Looks good, will let you know when I get one made mate, thanks for that it should save a bit of time fiddling :o)
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: Here's a thought for you, now that you have your printer working again.
comments.author: hughee

comments.text:
Done!
V005 released
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: Trés trés belle version , je vais imprimer et tester , merci a toi pour ton travail de fou :-)
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
Merci ;)
cette version marche mieux que je ne l'esperait pour moi. Mais attention j'utilise une buse MK8, qui est plus haute que celle d'origine...donc je peux pas te garantir une compatibilité a 100%. Si jamais ca ne passe pas, tu peux toujours couper ou poncer les 2 ouvertures parallelement au plan du lit.
comments.author: Boo54

comments.text:
keep in mind that's still a work in progress...
that's far to be my best upgrade, mine works a few time but as i printed it in PLA, it melts and skew and it works as if i was blowing from one single side....
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: Sounds like a great plan, Z tower can go on the back burner for a wee while :)
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
Super boulot, je cherchais justement un modèle comme celui-là qui ne souffle pas uniquement sur un seul côté.
Concernant le nozzle : tu as pris quel diamètre ?
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
Bon je dois malheureusement admettre que c'est pas au top...en tout cas en PLA c'est pas assez durable. Il commence à se tordre a cause de la chaleur, et je commence à retrouver les memes defaults sur les overhangs qu'avec l'ancien conduit :/
A voir si il est plus durable en ABS...mais je suis qd mm decu.
J'ai dans l'idee de me pencher sérieusement sur l'integralité du bloc avec 2 ventilos pour le refroidissement. En attendant tu peux toujours essayer celui la, en ABS si tu peux...
Sinon je te conseil la petite upgrade de l'extruder que j'ai fait, ca j'en suis vraiment satisfait :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1548736
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
J'avais eu le même souci avec un conduit de refroidissement en PLA.
En ABS ça tient mieux effectivement, je testerai à l'occasion :)
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text: version LED dispo!
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
Excellent, c'est du bon travail ça !
Par contre il n'y a aucune info sur les LED, ils ne précisent pas la tension, tu as utilisé une résistance ? Connectées en série ?
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text: Apres reflexion une resistance d'un demi kilo n'est pas de trop! 600Ohm (+/-50)
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
non il n'y a pas d'info, j'ai un peu bataillé pour savoir comment faire.
Chaque diode (3 par LED) accepte une tension de 2.8-3V. En soudant 2 LED en serie ( ce qui fait donc 3 paires de diode en parallele) j'ai mesuré un courant de 0.03A sur du 12V. Donc pas besoin de resistances.
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
;) merci
y'a encore quelque retouches a faire, et j'aimerais trouver le moyen d'y ajouter une led
comments.author: Yoshimura

comments.text:
I must try the new nozzle, even though I'm getting reasonable prints with thedayowl's original fan cowl setup, i'm still getting problems with overhangs at times. I've tried lowering the filament temp but that only helps a little. Hopefully this will provide a bit more cooling all round.
I printed thedayowl's original in PLA and it's been great for months now, no sign of melting or distortion where it gets close to the heater block.
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: upgraded
comments.author: hughee

comments.text:
i've print it in PLA (i still don't have any heat bed) and i was worrying if it will distort or even melt, but as far i test it, it still works well, even after long session without using the cooling fan ':)
But keep in mind that i only print PLA, so I didn't go over 140 °C. This should be printed in ABS for more heat resistance and durability.
I forgot to put that it is still a work in progress, i recently figure out that air flow is not perfectly convergent. However it already do a nice job for me...
comments.author: hughee

title: Filament Management system for coils or spools

description.text: This is yet another filament management system, but this one works with spools, and most coils. I've tested this with spools from makerbot, 3dprinterstuff, and ultimachine, all without problem, and then coils from ultimachine and makerbot. I've got about 100 hours on this thing without a tangle. So it's pretty wonderful! If there's interest, let me know, and I'll put some kits together on Indiegogo.

To build, cut the parts with a lasercutter, one each out of 5.7mm material, and they slip and lock together. Then just plug the PTFE tubing into  the bulkhead connector, and attach it to the hole in the spire. Then just set the turntable in the center and you're good to go. Spools go directly on the turntable, coils go on top of the spool.

description.text:
FPV Evil Insect Quadcopter
1.8 ounces of pure evil

This is my version of a micro FPV Quadcopter. After building and flying PunkKills' Micro 105 quad copter I decided to design my own frame. I wanted something evil. This uses all the same hardware from the Micro 105 such as:

  • Flight Controller: MicroScisky

  • Motors: Hubsan X4 H107c 8.5mm Motors

  • VTX: FX758-2 5.8G 200mW Video Transmitter

  • 5V Regulator: Polulu

  • Antenna: I used a piece of enamel coated magnet wire. After soldering the wire on, I cut the antenna to about 2" long which roughly the wavelength of that frequency.

  • Camera: 170 Degree Wide Angle Camera

  • Battery: 500mAh single cell batteries

  • Props: I am currently using Ladybird props. They hold up quite well through many crashes

Videos
https://youtu.be/Ecid_GzmEEU

https://youtu.be/VhEhn08dhzc

https://youtu.be/uz3-Hmp7Ya8

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 Layer

Infill:

0%

Notes:

The wall thikness is .4mm with no infill. I set the support to touching the bed only, and set the angle to 70 degrees with 15% fill. This made it relatively easy to dig the support out of the shell.

The frame is very thin light and flexible and so far has bounced after every crash with no failures. I even dropped this out of the sky from about 50 feet up once. The crash destroyed two of my motors, but the frame and all of the internal components survived.

First...nods to Skimbal for the original design and files.  
Ok...I printed the Bathtub U-boat and loved it. Looked great and once painted looked even better. It's on the wall by my desk at work and I got lot's of compliments.  
What could make it cooler???  
I know...what if I scaled it 200% ??? That's a sub almost 6 feet long and almost 11" around with the conning tower.   
I haven't finished mine..I've spent 20 or so hours scaling, cutting, reformatting, and printing test parts. I attached a picture with the first 5 pieces glued together (I also already printed the fattest middle hull section...which is beside the glued hull pieces).   
Once I get the hull done I'll take the add on pack (deck guns, periscopes, etc) and scale them up too....

Ok...let me say this Makerware CHOKES on this when using the standard slicer....error..error..error...  
So I used Skenforge (default) to slice these...it takes a Loooooong time though..usually an hour each. There were printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2.  
Then the printing takes an average of 9 hours for each part of the hull and there's 14 pieces to the hull...so you're looking at, realistically, close to 140 hours to print.   
Pretty sure the Skeinforge defaults are (10% fill, 2 walls, and .27 layer height)...NO raft.

description.text: Update Oct 2017: This Thing is here for archival reasons. In my own shop it has been completely supplanted by this system https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2362788 which I believe to be vastly superior. Original: Ever since my filament collection got past 3 or 4 spools I've been searching for the holy grail that would allow me to change filaments quickly without handling spools. It didn't take too long to figure out that if random access is a requirement, a separate holder for each spool is needed. That narrows the field pretty much to two approaches: holders on which a spool sits, bearing on its edges, and holders that involve an axle through a spool's hub. The former, in order to yield acceptably low friction, require ball or roller bearings. Since I wanted to accommodate 40+ spools, this approach was ruled out as too complex and time-consuming. I wanted something consisting of a few simple printed parts and a press-fit assembly process that would allow me to bang out 40+ holders in a few days. The TInkertoy-like result is presented here. Every single filament end is within arms' reach and I can change filaments without touching a spool. Only 7 different printed parts are necessary to cover most spool sizes on the market, at least the ones I use. These include 200x70mm (MakerBot, Prototype Supply), 160x90mm (Octave), 200x55mm (pp3dp, Bendlay), 220x55 (3dprintingsystems.com), Taulman, and others. A really nice aspect of the system is that you can have multiple rows of spools, one behind the other, to maximize storage in a given shelf space. Simply feed the rear spools' filament under the front spool(s) and through its guide loop. One of the attached videos shows a rear spool in action. Use of rubber feet, especially on rear-row spools, is strongly recommended, to prevent them from creeping forward and touching spools in front. Another great side benefit is that I've now removed the spool holders and spools previously attached to the printers, liberating at least a square foot of precious bench space. The "funnel" attached to a gantry directly above the printer(s) is not strictly necessary, but it's convenient, keeps filament from dangling in front of my monitor, keeps all the filament ends in one place, and reduces the sideways force vector on the printer when its feeding spool is located some distance off to the side. The foam in the funnel cleans the filament, and more importantly, helps tame the unruly mass of protruding filament ends. Since it won't be easy to change the foam with 40 filaments going through it, you might want to have a separate, easily-changeable cleaner foam located at each printer. Video of the FSS in action: http://youtu.be/DE9xbywAdiQ http://youtu.be/HNsTqzcEDbo http://youtu.be/r5bAiAoVQeA Full construction details are in the Instructions section. All printed parts are available on Tinkercad, search for "FSS".

You will need some 1/4" diameter oak dowels (don't use pine, use oak), and some 1" and 1-1/2" black "poly" pipe (shown in the photos), available at home improvement stores. Regular PVC pipe's wall thickness is too big, and will NOT fit in many spool hubs. You can also use thin-wall styrene tubing sold by plastics supply companies. For Taulman spools you need to find something smaller; I happened to have some styrene tubing around that fit, but you could use copper pipe. I strongly recommend adding stick-on rubber feet to keep spools from sliding around. The ones I use are made by 3M and available from Mouser here: http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/3M-Electronic-Specialty/SJ-5312-CLEAR/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMs6x5FGDTpfsNuah9WR6FTsRPC5T%252b4YqOk%3d for about $0.06 each. The accompanying Excel document lists the axle diameters, axle lengths, and support dowel lengths for the various spool sizes supported. You don't need to saw the dowels - simply measure them off, making score marks with a pair of diagonal cutters, as shown in the photos. Once scored you can snap them off with your fingers or cut them with a pair of compound-leverage lineman's pliers. Don't worry about the getting the lengths exactly right, and don't bother to sand the ends clean. It's all very forgiving of a few mm here or there. The axle tubing is best cut with a power mitre ("chop") saw. If you use a hand saw I recommend a mitre box, otherwise the ends will not be square and the axles will be prone to falling out of the bearings. The press-fit of the dowels into the printed parts is nice and snug, but easily done by hand (at least with parts printed on my Up). The front-back braces for the large-spool holders are optional, and I find them unnecessary if stick-on rubber feet are used; the oak dowels are very stiff and splay is minimal. Without rubber feet they might be more necessary. There is also provision for "pinning" the front-back supports with small sheet metal screws if you want the ultimate in rigidity and stability. Just drive them into the dowels with your screwdriver.

comments.text: After having built my prusi i3 nearly 1yr ago, I have accumulated several spools --- even ones I cant use (3mm filament I thought I might be upgradeing to use someday) -  even a seemingly painfully heavy 'multispool' (has 4 colors on one spool)  - That is an ingenious method of 'bringing' the material together , funelling it into easier access without fumbling around for a spool, likely that most hobbyiests do ...  A desk, a hutch/shelf system and some of those printed holders ...  -- I can think of a simpler design,   a single PVC pipe going through all the spools; you may have touched on this aspect of differing inner spool diameters being an issue, and now that I look , the weight will cause sagging, which is easily remidied with a support at sag points. In reality, it has to be tried and tested to say 'it works well !' (a 2nd, smaller diam. pvc pipe for the smaller spools), sched 80 is the thicker.

comments.author: worldburger

comments.text: Thanks, worldburger. I find that it's best to use a ball-bearing or other low-friction axle bearing for flexible filaments and make sure there's nothing else in the filament path that adds tension, lest the filament stretch, become thin, and slip in the extruder drive. So I don't use my main FSS with Ninja or Fila, I have a dedicated printer and ball-bearing hubs for them.
comments.author: worldburger

comments.text: This is a spool farm that really works for me. I have about 30 spools on the top shelf of a 6" X 4" shelving unit, with my printers on the shelf just below. There's room on the shelf for a total of about 40 spools, depending on the footprint of the various sized spool bases in use. I have spools of PLA/618 to the left and ABS/conductive to the right. With this matrix arrangement of spools, the filaments from spools in the back row flow through the bases of the spool frames in front of it. This keeps the filament strands relatively straight even when they want to spiral more and more as the spool empties out.
comments.author: neobobkrause

comments.text: Sweet. Well enough thought out to be simple. This is the rig I'm going to build my printing station around. Thanks.
comments.author: neobobkrause

comments.text: Thanks, Bob, for your kind words. One thing I'm finding with use is that it doesn't always pay to route filament through the funnel if means coming from way over on one side and then back again in the same direction it came from to get to the printer - it's just wasted drag. In those cases I'm going straight from the spool to the printer without bother to go through the central funnel. Each spool holder has a couple of holes for storing the loose end when not in use anyway. I would also cut back on the number of foam support members in the funnel since they can cause excess drag as well. Or maybe just get rid of the foam holder there and make it a simple torus.

comments.text: Do you live in a dry environment?  Just wondering if having all that filament sitting out for prolonged periods has caused any moisture problems.
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text: My shop is air conditioned; it's in the Northeast USA, which is dry in winter and humid in summer, but the indoor environment is fairly constant and well-controlled. I know a lot of users are meticulous about trying to keep their filament dry (I'm not sure how effective all that tupperware and silica gel really is), but I've only ever noticed moisture-related issues with nylon, never with ABS. I have a lab oven for drying nylon, but I don't use nylon much anyway.

description.text: Updated the original design to match the current Prusa x-carriage mounting holes and for 3mm filament. Should be easy to add 1.75mm support as well if needed. I've verified things fit together as it should, but still waiting on my tubing to arrive so listing as a work in progress till I verify everything. Sources (including openscad files): https://github.com/mattsch/Prusa3Bowden Edit: installed and working, pics to follow.

J-Head Mk V-BV:
https://www.hotends.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=88 Fitting (1/4" BSPT, 6mm OD): http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004M8T26Y This doesn't use locknuts since they require more space than is really reasonable for this mount. Just heat up the fitting mount area (and/or fitting threads) and screw the fitting in slowly. That should create nice tight threads in the plastic and hold quite well.

author: JFG7662

title: ABS indicator holder to level Rep 2 build plate

description.text:
NOTE:  This Thing is probably not water-tight.  It prints out perfectly in ABS on my MakerBot Replicator 2X.  
If you've spent much time leveling your printer's build plate (and you should, as it is probably the most important part of a successful build) you know how tedious and aggravating it can be.  Having a dial indicator and a jig of this type, which sits on the 8mm rails of the gantry is a real time saver, and more accurate than using a piece of paper.  
You will need to move the gantry (and the jig) around by hand, after bringing the build plate up high enough to engage the tip of the indicator.  Do not use this with the built-in leveling routine of the printer.  Zero the indicator, and adjust the three leveling screws below the build plate as needed to get the indicator to read 0 in all positions.  If the build plate is a bit warped, you should still be able to 0 it in four corners.

For this Thing I took measurements of my new MakerBot Replicator 2X, from the rails of the gantry system (both their distance apart and their diameter), and the allowance needed for the X-axis belt.  Of course trial and error needed to be made to allow for shrinkage of the ABS filament during building.  After two builds I felt I had the measurements I needed and the third build fit very well.  
For the indicator I chose the Anytime Tools Digital Electronic Indicator (available from Amazon, p/n AT203188).  The hole for the indicator is a standard 9.47mm (3/8") dia.  I found this a press fit, but it could be reamed as well.  Holes are provided for rare earth magnets (Radio Shack p/n 64-1895).  These are 1.51mm thick, and a nice press fit that should put them just above the rails when in use.  They hold the jig very well.  Start installing them by placing them by hand as level as possible above the holes.  Drive home with a blunt plastic object until level below the holes.  I've included thru-holes to allow a 1/16" drill bit to be used to push the magnets out again if you have problems.  
A pilot hole is included in one side in case you want to drill and tap for a set screw to hold your indicator in place.  
As for the settings, use ABS (I used Octave 1.75mm ABS), Standard setting (.20mm layer height), with a 10% infill, 3 shells, 230C extruder temp, and build plate at 115C, with a raft.  Lay the jig on its back on the build plate so that no support is needed

comments.text:
I have one that was made by another guy. Pretty cool idea too.
Yours is not adjustable and is intended for one type of printer. the 8mm rods I have are not the same distance apart. Maybe you can update yours to be adjustable via a slider and bolt to tighten it. ;) Just a thought.
comments.author: SteveC

comments.text: This is, as described, for the MakerBot Rep 2 series (Rep 2 and 2x).  Any adaptation would have to be a whole new animal.  There are many out there.  Mine is based on some of these.  I feel any changes would decrease the accuracy that is possible.

This is my own version of a Bob Beck magnet pulser. I used an Arduino Uno with an Arduino 5v relais for the timer switch part of this device. It pulses every 5 seconds 1 pulse 0.2 second long. I made the casing and other parts with 3D printed parts on a Velleman K8200. Red filament is PetG. Make up your own damn mind if this technology works or not. It helps me and family members a lot with several afflictions and injuries. This device is for those parts of the human body where are no blood vessels where the 'blood purifier' (see other publication) can do his work. More information at www.bobbeck.com. This device is for my daughter Miek.

Caution! There are high voltages involved while you work on this device. Always stay away from the 5 capacitors when the casing is open and the device is on. When you stop using the device switch it off and let the device do two more pulses, then unplug the device from the mains. The capacitors are discharged this way. I'm not responsible for any injuries using this publication.

This is another reprap gen 6 electronics enclosure. It's pretty good looking, and has space for a power entry module, with switch. Keeps everything looking nice!
If there's interest, let me know, and I'll try and put some kits together, but with a hinged lid.

Laser cut all parts out of 5.7 mm material
Stain if desired.
Push sides onto bottom.
Insert m3 nuts into t slots, followed by m3X16 machine screws, and tighten down. 
Put PSU into the bottom, and use 4 m4x12 screws and washer to mount the PSU.
Mount power entry module, with 2 m3x12 screws and nuts. 
Mount the gen6 board with connectors facing the top, and usb connector pointing forward, using 4 15mm m3 standoffs. 
Using .25" quick disconnect flag terminals, and .2" fork terminals connect the power entry module to the psu. 
Using 2 more .3" fork terminals attach the 12v from the psu to the "Euro connector" on the main board. 
Button it all up and connect wiring to the gen6 board as labeled.

title: 37mm ND Filter Mount for DJI Phantom 3 Standard

description.text: This is an ND filter for your Phantom 3 Standard, which will help reduce the Jello effect on bright days. There are plenty of ND filters for P3 Advanced and Professional, but the standard is lacking. What filters do exist are really expensive. This allows you to press-fit any standard 37mm filters (I got mine on Amazon) onto your lens. It is light enough that it doesn't interfere with the gimbal or hit the ground. Print time around 30 minutes on an Ultimaker 2.

As I am a total beginner with drones, I designed some propguards for my 250 ZMR China clone quadrocopter. It comes with 2204 2300KV motors, so I checked the datasheet and made the mounting holes accordingly.
I intentionally didn't make the guard too thick, because I wanted it to break before parts of the frame break, especially the arms. Each weights 10 gramms.
I had several testflights with the current version 3.1, the propguards work fine and saved me some propellers.

I hope you enjoy them, and If there is need to make anything better, don't hesitate to leave a comment.

EDIT:
The guard has a diameter of 156mm, thats appx. 6''.
I'm flying with 5030 propellers.

title: Makergear M2 extruder end filament guide holder

description.text:
I found the filament guide (aka teflon tube) kept over-stressing my filament while idle, and I actually had the filament break at the right as it goes into the extruder.   
This supports the filament guide and just seems to make the filament handling a bit nicer.  
Problem solved.

You will need a M4X20mm SHC screw to replace the existing M4 filament tensioner screw. I added an M3X12mm SHC and nut to allow some pressure on the tube, but dont really think its needed.  
Remove the existing M4 screw and nut, slip in the printed part, shove the M4X20 through the hole and add the nut. Optionally, you can hold the tube in with a M3X12 SHC screw and nut in the obvious place.

remixed_from.author: franklima260
remixed_from.title: Handle for 2.5 mm Allen Key / Hex Key

description.text: I found this great handle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:129760 for hex wrenches. However it was for only one size. I've create a customizable version so you can create your own for different size keys.

The best approach is to use the customizer, although you can download one of the STL files if it matches the size of your key.  
To use the customizer, measure the width of the key, when rotated so it's the widest (as shown in the photo with the digital calipers). Enter this number as the diameter for the hole.  
By default, the slot is increased in size by 0.15mm to compensate for differences in printing. You can adjust this to make it looser or tighter.  
You can also change the diameter of the handle. I prefer the 25mm size that is the default.

comments.text:
You should really put a height customizer in the thingiverse Customizer app. It's ALREADY in the scad file. Would be almost no issue to do, and would probably be a lot better for other people. I've checked, and already made a little stubby one to save time and plastic.
Anyway, thanks for the design!

This is a collection of all the letters to make anybody's name. This was done in Inventor so if you have that you can create the name as an assembly first. Otherwise, load the letters that you need and adjust the coordinates so they overlap.   
For instance in Repetier-Host, I would load the letters. Set the Y coordinates to be the same, then adjust the X-coordinates so they overlap a little. Then when you go to slice it and it tells you things overlap, quit or no, you say no. It will sclice it just fine.

title: Quick Release Filament Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a low friction filament holder which has been designed with a quick release hub. I wanted to create a filament holder which could sit on a table or mount on a wall, as a result I ended up with a design which traps the spool hubs bearings.

I have included a Solid works file of the hub and latch to help in your designs. I may refine the design in the future as the bearing fits snug but loosens over time.

Hub Assembly:
2 x 624-2r2 Bearings (13mm OD. x 4mm ID. x 5mm width)
2 x 4mm x 30mm Button Head Screw
2 x 4mm nuts

Spooler Stand:
2 x 3mm x 16mm Socket Head Screw
2 x 3mm nuts
2 x 3mm washers
2 x 1/4-20 threaded rod
8 x 1/4-20 nuts
4 x rubber self adhering feet. (Optional)

NOTE: The hub design was inspired by the Spool holder with bearings http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:467008

Printer:

Afinibot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

80%

Notes:

The Supports are only needed on the threaded spooler shaft and the spooler sides.

Spooler Hub Assembly

The threads for the spool hub and shaft may bind when first assembled. If you slowly thread the hubs on and off the threaded shaft eventually they will spin freely... I ended up using a little tooth past to help sand the threads.

Mandible Hub

After printing the hub may have some rafting material along the bearing path. In order for the bearing to lock in place it is important to make sure the bearing can seat all the way in. Take the time to clean the path for the bearing. If you are having trouble getting the bearing to seat all the way down, then you could use a small handheld butane torch, to heat the seat and then press the bearing into position.

This model produces front and back pieces for a game case suitable for a creating a portable Super Nintendo using a PS1 screen, SNES controller, and SNES mini console. It was created using OpenSCAD, with netfabb for repair, and was my first major experience using CAD. The visual design was inspired by the fantastic Supertendo. There are two issues to be aware of with these models. First, they lack internal screw posts; I added those as I was building. Second, the plate behind the cartridge slot doesn't have much support, and sagged a bit when printed, warping the back piece slightly. This didn't really end up being much of a problem, but is something I would fix before I would print another. OpenSCAD source code for this model is available at https://github.com/tdoug870/snesp

title: Diamond Fan Duct with Lighting
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I very much liked the Hesine Prusa i3 Fan Duct Upgrade, especially the outlets, on
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1183788
but it didn't fit on my Hesine Prusa i3.
I also liked the Diamond Hotend Blower Fan Mount with added LED Ring support,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911229
although I did find the reflection on the glass bed a bit too much.

Then I got a diamond hot end.
So I tried to design (partly imitate) a combination of the two, from the bottom up, in FreeCAD and this is the first result.

I printed it in PLA with PVA as supporting matierial, the first one that succeeded a bit with my diamond. Now I am waiting for some other stuff to be able to really try it out.

Already I found that the light reflection, now on the top of this thing, is still a bit too much, so I reckon that I will make some sort of collar on top, possibly only on the front side, where it matters most.
And indeed I have added a design with collar (see the last pictures) plus it's .stl file, but be warned: it is untried. As soon as my printer is functional again, I'll try and print it and show it.

Followup:
For the time being none of the above, I am sorry to say.
I gave up for now on the diamond hot end, because of the constant clogging of the tubes within the heatsinks with different PLA filaments, cleaning filament and whatnot.
Undoubtedly my fault, but after many many hours of declogging, I don't know what to do any more.
So now I am unable to print the 2nd version, which also needs printing with support from a soluble filament, I am sure, or to do the promised try outs.
No progress on this work, alas.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 (Hesine)

No

Yes

30% - 3D Honeycomb - Hilbert

Notes:

layer height: 0.3mm

Support pattern: pillars.
Contact Z distance: 0 (soluble)

I have forgotten my old leather wallet so often that I might as well have thrown it away long ago. The problem is that it is so bulky that I can not sit with it in my pocket - I then take it out of my pocket and leaves it at friends, in the office or the restaurant.

What I wanted is something very simple. It should only hold four cards - my visa card, my social security card, driver's licens and the key card for my online banking.

I decided against having a clip for bank notes, as I hardly ever have any, and if I do, they can stay in my pocket together with coins and keys.

When you have printed two parts (or more, if you want multiple compartments), you combine them with five rubber band. I have used 15x2 mm O-rings (because that was want I had at home), but I think I will recommend something less rigid, as it is very tight and I had some work with tweezers to fit them in.

description.text:
Adapt a digital caliper for checking bed level on the UIltimaker. I used this device:
LCD Digital Tread Depth Gauge Gage Inch Metric 0.0005 Tire Thread Electronic ($4.95) http://cgi.ebay.ca/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=350809115884

Drill out the bolt holes with a 6mm drill because the plastic bits make it very tight.  
The digital depth gauge drops into this holder, and the extender fits over depth bar to reach the print bed.  
The depth gauge sits lightly in the holder so that it can be removed during printing.  
Pull the rod up while manually moving the print head to different areas of the bed, then push the rod back down and adjust the bed height level screws accordingly.

remixed_from.title: LCD Mount for ORD Bot Hadron

title: JD LCD Panel Mount for RRD Smart LCD Controller onto Ord Bot Hadron

description.text:
This panel mounts RepRap Discount's Smart LCD Controler to the header panel of the Ord Hadron.  
I used the basic idea of another Ord LCD mount panel (see the remixed from section), but drew a new one with tighter perimeter edges, standoff spacers, added a hole for the contrast adjustment pot, added rounded corners, notches for the cables and support standoffs for the lower edge of LCD panel.  
Photos should be coming soon.

I used a laser engraver with settings appropriate for the material used.  
The LCD panel mount can be made of anything, I used 6mm thick acrylic for the mount. The smallest six holes can be drilled to 2.5mm (or #39 drill bit) and tapped the hole to M3 x 0.5 thread.  I used 4x M3 x 16 and 2x M3 x 20mm screws.  
If you don't have an M3 x 0.5mm tap, you can drill the six small holes to 2.8mm or #40, and  thread the screws in, the material should form around the screw.  
The spacers work best if cut from 3mm thick material. They stack 3 per screw on the panel corners, 5 per screw on the lower LCD module.

This is a replacement washer for the original LEM nylon washer for #5, 8 and 12 Big Bite meat grinders.

I needed a replacement nylon washer for my LEM #5 meat grinder and found that LEM wants $5.99 for it. I thought this was too high and decided to try designing and printing one of my own. EDIT: I just contacted LEM and they said on top of the $5.99 for the washer, they'd charge me $5.99 for shipping. That's ridiculous! $12 for a washer that cost them probably 5 cents to make. I am loving this printer, yep yep -- gonna pay for itself in no time.

So here is the OpenSCAD file and STL file.

Dimensions are right on. I'll be testing it out soon.

I printed it in PLA so I am wondering how it will hold up compared to the original Nylon version -- we'll see. Perhaps it would be better if I bought some PETG and printed using that instead?

It only cost 11 cents to print one out, so I'd be happy if it lasted even 1/4th as long. I printed in "clear/transparent" PLA so it more closely resembles the original one.

Print at 100% infill and .1 layer height for more strength (at least my intuition is telling me that .1 layer height is stronger than .2 layer height, but I could be wrong? )

EDIT: 4/24/2016: Did a dry run and it seems to be working fine. The first few passes it broke off a tiny amount of PLA plastic, but once it was properly broken in it isn't shedding anymore. It only shedded dandruff size flakes -- about a dozen particles each time. Then it quit. Seems to be functioning like the original. I popped the original in right after and it seemed to behave the same.

comments.text: Ground up about 15 pounds of brisket the other day with this washer.  Worked fine :)
